708288f-a.title: Manhattan: 4th Avenue - 32nd Street
708288f-a.text:
Fourth Avenue, west side, from 32nd to 34th Streets, showing the old Park Avenue Hotel and the new Vanderbilt Hotel nearing completion. The view is from the roof of the old Fourth Avenue Railway (Metropolitan Railway) carbarns. At the N.W. corner of 34th Street, the first building on that side of Park Avenue, stands the Unitarian Church of the Messiah, later known as the
Comnunity Church, erected in 1867.
To the right, on the east side of the Avenue opposite the Vanderbilt Hotel, stands the 71st Regiment Armory (1893).
1911.

722025f.title: Manhattan: Park Avenue - 32nd Street
722025f.text:
Park Avenue between 32nd and 33rd Streets, looking west from the excavation on the east of the avenue.
In the foreground the old street railway carbarns have been demolished, and the ground is being prepared for the 18-story office building to be called No. 1 Park Avenue. On the N, E. corner of 33rd Street stands the 71st Regiment Armory. On the west side between 32nd and 33rd Streets, the old Park Avenue Hotel is shortly to be demolished and replaced by another office building. Opposite the Armory stands
the Vanderbilt Hotel (erected 1911).
1925.
Drix Duryea, Photographer.
MAY BE REPRODUCED with credit.

722020f-a.title: Manhattan: Park Avenue - 32nd Street
722020f-a.text:
Park Avenue, east side, north fromu 3End Street, showing the new 0ne Park Avenue building, just comupleted, the 7lst Regiment Armory, and the new Fred F. French apartment houses on the S. E. corner
of 35th Street.
April 1926.
Brown Brothers, Photographers.

722024f-a.title: Manhattan: Park Avenue - 32nd Street
722024f-a.text:
Park Avenue, east side, north from 32nd Street, showing the SeventyFirst Regiment Armory (1893) from 33rd to 34th Streets, with a little of the new Number One Park Avenue building visible on the S.E.
corner of 33rd Street.
In the background the Pew York Central Building at 46th Street
rises over the Trand Central Station.
March 27, 1929.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

708287f-a.title: Manhattan: 4th Avenue - 32nd Street
708287f-a.text:
Looking south on Fourth Avenue from lPark Avenue at 32nd Street;
east side.
Skyline of lower Manhattan msy be seen faintly in the background.
February 27, 1931.
P.L. Sperr, photographer.

722026f-a.title: Manhattan: Park Avenue - 32nd Street (East)
722026f-a.text:
Park Avenue, east side, from E. 32nd (right) to 33rd (left) Streets, showing the New York and narlem Railroad carbarns. The pnotographer is viewing samo in a south eastward direction from: a vantage pont at the N. W. corner of Park AVenue and E. 33rd Street
(Vanderbilt Rotel today).
At the time this photo was taken, this thoroughfare was Fourth Avenue; Park avenue oegining at 34th Street. .hen the present multi story building No. 1 Park Nvenue was erected,this Avenue was extended southward to begin at 32nd Street. In the renumbering, this office building took the number formerly held by Mrs. Bacon at the N. E. corner of Park evenue and E. 34th Street. Behind the board fence in the foreground ran the trains to Harlem, tnru the tunnel to Grand .entral Station at 42nd Street. It was here that the famous Cunnel Gang originated and from which came Boss .rocker of Tammany, a worthy successor to Boss Tweed. In earlier days this was tne bed of Sunfish Pond. The ground slope clearly seen here indicates the size and depth of
Same.
Remaining today (1939) are only two of the buildings appearing here. They are tne 4 story structure seen at the left margin and the St. Stepnen's Roman Catholic Church at the right. No. 197 Lexington Avenue, the first mentioned, is now an automobile garage.
1860's

722028f-a.title: Manhattan: Park Avenue - 32nd Street
722028f-a.text:
Park Ave., east side, north from but not including 32nd Street,
to and including 33rd Street.
January, 1924.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
